instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board, that has green light in magsafe and turns red after as few secs, but has no fanspin and no power, and consumes only 0.028A on bench PSU

I have 5V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> but on <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> I get 0V

It has no signs of liquid contact.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Do you have original charger?
Be aware, it doesn't turn on with 45/60W charger, unless battery is connected and holds some charge.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
We do try with original charger (2) but no response. Now I'm testing it with only the board on the bench.
I do have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, but I don't have have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> (0V).
On <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, w/o battery, I have 0V.
I've checked on <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR> and both 0V. <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR> seams to be OK (97ohms)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Is that original charger 85W for sure?
Check its real power with other machine (in system report).
Just in case, try to turn on with both charger and battery connected.

Is the battery charging?
